awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Does Liebig's Law Allow for Capturing More Signal from the Forest?
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop and apply a tree growth model in order to strengthen the recovery of climate signals (temperature and moisture) recorded in the width of tree-ring. This tree growth model has the potential to improve large-scale climate reconstructions and will be useful for understanding and ameliorating systematic differences between instrumental and tree-ring climate reconstructions. The growth model is based on the Liebig's law of the minimum which describes how tree growth is dictated by the most limiting factor (e.g. sunlight, nutrients, moisture). The researchers will:  1) conduct a comprehensive analysis of 4,213 tree-ring sites from the International Tree Ring Data Bank to understand how Liebig's Law influences within-stand variability; and 2) characterize the ways that Liebig's Law influences the distribution of climate signal across trees in both a model and observational context. The goal of this project is to develop reconstruction techniques for inverting growth for temperature or precipitation in the presence of local limitations on growth. These reconstruction techniques have the potential to result in substantially improved reconstructions of local and regional climate variability. 

The potential Broader Impacts include new methodologies to use tree growth and tree-ring proxies for climate reconstructions. A dendroclimatology field-based class to first-year students at San Francisco State University (a designated Minority Serving Institution by the Department of Education) will be developed, with the goal of recruiting minority and economically disadvantaged students to the Earth Sciences. The project will support the education and training of two graduate students. The researchers will incorporate concepts and results from this project in their respective classes and outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In our project, "Does Liebig's Law Allow for Capturing More Signal from the Forest?", we aimed to develop and apply methodologies to strengthen the recovery of climate signals recorded in tree-ring records.

A primary result of our work regards exploration of the nonlinear response of tree ring record to climate and the ability to invert this relationship for reconstruction of drought.  Specifically, in "Regional Nonlinear Relationships Across the United States Between Drought and Tree-Ring Width Variability From a Neural Network" we used a two-layer neural network to reconstruct summertime self-calibrated Palmer Drought Severity Index (scPDSI) across the contiguous United States. We showed that reconstructions using neural networks are more skillful than a linear approach at 75% of the grid boxes if evaluated by the coefficient of efficiency and at 54% when using the Pearson correlation coefficient. The increased reconstruction skill is related to the network capturing nonlinear growth-climate relationships. In the Southwest, in particular, a nonlinear response function captures a diminishing sensitivity of growth to moisture under wetter conditions, consistent with alleviation of moisture stress. These results indicate somewhat less-severe and more-stable incidences of drought over the past two centuries in the U.S. Southwest.

In another study, "The influence of decision-making in tree ring-based climate reconstructions", led by Ulf B?ntgen, we helped quantify the uncertainty associated with the fact that reconstructions of Common Era climate are derived using different datasets and techniques. Specifically, we contributed to a double-blind experiment that, in total, yielded 15 Northern Hemisphere summer temperature reconstructions from a common network of regional tree-ring width datasets. The mean reconstruction correlates with instrumental temperatures from 1794?2016 CE at 0.79 (p < 0.001), revealing summer cooling in the years following large volcanic eruptions and exhibiting strong warming since the 1980s. The ensemble members, however, demonstrate the influence of subjectivity in the reconstruction process by differing in their mean, variance, amplitude, sensitivity, and persistence.  We recommend the routine use of ensemble reconstruction approaches to provide a more consensual picture of past climate variability.

Two other papers emerged from consideration of forcing of paleoclimate variability and consideration of the conditions under which forest forest occur.   In ?Global Surface Temperature Response to 11-Yr Solar Cycle Forcing Consistent with General Circulation Model Results?, we characterized the sensitivity of temperature in instrumental records, simulations, and proxies to solar variability.  The sensitivity of temperature to solar forcing was contentious, with empirical best estimates of global surface temperature sensitivity to solar forcing range from 0.08 to 0.18 K per (W m2). In comparison, best estimates from general circulation models forced by solar variability are smaller and having prompted speculation that physical mechanisms not included in general circulation models may amplify responses to solar variability. Using a lagged multiple linear regression method, we found a sensitivity of global-average surface temperature ranging between 0.02 and 0.09 K per (W m22), consistent with foregoing simulation-based estimates. 

In "Microwave Retrievals of Soil Moisture Improve Grassland Wildfire Predictions" we evaluated the degree to which Soil moisture provides a measure of water availability that is complimentary to vapor pressure deficit (VPD) for predicting wildfires.  Receiver operating characteristic curves estimated from 1,907 fires in the Western U.S. indicated that inclusion of soil moisture in addition to VPD observations permits for more skillful prediction (p < 0.05). When VPD already signals high risk, the addition of soil moisture reduces the false positive rate grasslands (from 75% to 62%), shrublands (76% to 67%), and forests (74% to 68%) for a true positive rate of 75%. These results demonstrated potential to improve daily fire risk models with the addition of remotely sensed soil moisture.
The Broader Impacts include new methodologies to use tree growth and tree-ring proxies for climate reconstructions.  The broader impacts include the support and education of a Master?s student at San Francisco State University and the completion of a PhD by a graduate student at Harvard University. The PIs also incorporated concepts and results from this project in their respective classes and outreach activities.
